inlineContent.text: Starting from version

of Mapbox Maps SDK you can now use a declarative approach to add or update style primitives such as Sources, Layers, Images, and Lights at runtime. This paradigm simplifies working with all Mapbox styles at runtime and works well in SwiftUI and UIKit applications.

As these features are experimental, there may be breaking changes between minor versions. In this period, we are especially interested in hearing feedback from developers like you! To provide feedback please open an issue in
repository. To opt-in, import MapboxMaps with the experimental SPI:
Declarative styling is available starting from iOS 13.
Then, you can use the
method, which is available in
and
instances.
In SwiftUI applications, simply place the style primitives inside the
content:
You don’t need to observe any events to modify the map style. Changes will be automatically applied when the map style is loaded.
Style primitives are pieces of map content that can be added, updated, and removed at runtime. These primitives represent the data sources and visualization choices for your map.
You can use a builder syntax to modify the properties of your style primitives when you add them to your map. If you update these properties the changes will be reflected on your map.

code: // Create a atmosphere primitive and set properties for range, start intensity, and color

You can also use conditionals to add and remove map style primitives. In the example below,

is a variable controlled by your code, perhaps toggled when a user selects a button or changes a setting. When true, the Style Projection is set to Globe, terrain data is added to a RasterDem source and visualized with a Terrain map content. When toggled false, the terrain source and content are removed and the project is set to Mercator. Other content on the map is not affected by this change so updates are lightweight.

code: // To change your style content you should set new map primitives using
// This will fully change the displayed style content,
// so be sure to include all the content you want.

inlineContent.text: You can create your own primitives in addition to Mapbox style primitives. Defining your own primitives gives you greater control over when the content is updated, and allows for cleaner organization of your code. To create a primitive, declare a new struct which conforms to
and add your primitives to the
property.
For example, the code below creates a
which manages all you need to display a sport care Model on your map: the
for the data, the
to display, and the
used to position the model. Add your
to your style body just like Mapbox style primitives.
We recommend not using @State or @Binding as part of your custom primitives. @State will only work as part of root view that contain
. @Binding may work in your components, but it will break content recalculation logic and will lead to worse performance.

Our aim was to establish a single source of truth for all content displayed on the map through our declarative approach. Moreover, we invested significant efforts in automating the heavy lifting of manual layer positioning, seamlessly incorporating it into the declarative description.
Essentially, this means that all layers defined in the declarative description will be positioned on the map relative to each other, following a similar pattern as

Referring back to the example above, the order of layers will be: [default map style layers] -> [yellow polygon] -> [green polygon]. It’s worth noting that MapViewAnnotation doesn’t participate in layer ordering and will always be displayed above any layers.
In contrast to the imperative API, we intentionally removed the ability to set layer positions using the
modifier for

. This emphasizes that the order of layer declarations should precisely reflect the actual layer ordering. As a result, in the declarative API you cannot add runtime layers between style layers already in the Style.
So, despite the elegance of declarative ordering, there are scenarios where it falls short:
Placing layers between style layers that were not added at runtime.
Interoperability with traditional imperative APIs.
Slots API.
To address these scenarios, we introduced

, which slightly disrupts the elegance of declarative ordering but provides a crucial mechanism and single entry point for more advanced layer ordering cases. This ensures that the impact of this disruption to ordering remains minimal.
The following example demonstrates how
allows the addition of runtime slots, facilitating interactions with imperative APIs and dividing existing slots into more granular groups.

code: /// The MapStyleContent defines the desired layers positions.
/// The annotation uses slot `annotation-placeholder` so it will be rendered below the polygon:
/// If any other layers or annotations are added to the `annotation-placeholder` slot, they will appear above the triangle annotation, but below the square layer.

inlineContent.text: Another important feature of

. This effectively resolves the scenario where a developer needs to insert a runtime-added layer between style layers that are part of the Style JSON.

Custom style primitives can be used to optimize performance for resource-heavy tasks like loading a large GeoJson. For example, you may want to load a GeoJSON of point data only if a user selects a certain setting and only update it when explicitly desired. In this case, you can add a
variable. When toggled to true, an instance of your custom
struct conforming to
is added. This approach means that the features you add (in this case three points) will only be assessed for changes if the
reference is changed. This prevents unnecessary computation when the underlying GeoJSON data has not changed.

code: // The body gets called and the GeoJSON source data is updated only when the `features` reference is changed.
/// A reference wrapper over the array of features.
// The body gets called and the GeoJSON source data is updated only when the `features` reference is changed.
/// A reference wrapper over the array of features.

in our examples application.

abstract.text: Simplify runtime style manipulation with declarative syntax.
Map style import.
Provides access to the map model, including the camera, style, observable map events,
and querying rendered features.
A protocol used to create any type of  map style content, such as layers, sources, lighting and others.
Layer with custom rendering implementation
Location Indicator layer.
Describes a Custom Geometry Source to be used in the style
A raster tile source.
A layer to render 3D Models.
A structure represeting a Model
Marks the position of a slot.
A RGB-encoded raster DEM source
An extruded (3D) polygon.
Interactive, thoroughly customizable maps for iOS powered by vector tiles and Metal.
Raster map textures such as satellite imagery.
Client-side hillshading visualization based on DEM data. Currently, the implementation only supports Mapbox Terrain RGB and Mapzen Terrarium tiles.
An indirect light affecting all objects in the map adding a constant amount of light on them. It has no explicit direction and cannot cast shadows.
The global terrain source.
The background color or pattern of the map.
A filled polygon with an optional stroked border.
An image data source.
A light that has a direction and is located at infinite distance, so its rays are parallel. It simulates the sun light and can cast shadows.
A style’s fog property is a global effect that improves depth perception by fading out distant objects.
A spherical dome around the map that is always rendered behind all other layers.
Warning: As of v10.6.0,
is the preferred method for atmospheric styling. Sky layer is not supported by the globe projection, and will be phased out in future major release.
A heatmap.
Describes a Custom Raster Source to be used in the style.
A collection of
projection methods.
An icon or a text label.
Specifies the position at which a layer will be added when using
A stroked line.
A global directional light source which is only applied on 3D and hillshade layers. Using this type disables other light sources.
A SwiftUI view that displays a Mapbox Map.
A GeoJSON data source.
A filled circle.
A vector tile source.
Sets style content to the map.
The
control timing for the interpolation between a transitionable style
property’s previous value and new value. These can be used to define the style default property
transition behavior. Also, any transitionable style property may also have its own
property that defines specific transition timing for that specific layer property, overriding
the global transition values.
A utility class for capturing styled map snapshots.
